utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Three, two, one. Yeah! Whoo!

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: What do you want to do next? Uh, swings? Okay. Um, crawl tube?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Nah.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Nah? Well, I think we're running out of options, honey.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: I want to go on the merry-go-round.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: The m — again?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: But this time all by myself.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Oh. I don't know, jellybean.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Daddy, I'm six. I'm not a baby anymore. Please?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: You ready?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Uh-huh.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: All right. Come here. I'll take beary. Mm. Now you promise you're not gonna tell mommy, right? She'll kick my butt if she finds out.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Pinky swear.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: All right. Go get 'em.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Remember to hold on tight.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: I will.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Stop the ride!

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Emily! Emily, where are you?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Em? Emily? Emily? Emily, where are you, honey?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Oh, Em. Emily. Honey? Help me!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is that our precious little bundle of tumor? They grow up so fast, don't they?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How did you know I was here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How do you think?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Foreman.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, that would have been easier. No, I followed you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It didn't occur to you that that might mean I don't want you involved in my cancer treatment?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm not here as a doctor. I'm here as a towering pillar of strength.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Be a pillar in the parking lot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. How many times have I told you I wanted to be alone and you've made yourself a pain in the ass? I owe you. My word, not a word.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Realizing I'm most likely going to regret this, all right.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What — what are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My best friend has cancer. Cut me some slack. Also, spring break. I'm on vacation. Although looking at you now, I can tell the wet t-shirt contest is probably gonna suck.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: House taking time off is a bad sign.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: "A bad sign." You think the apocalypse is coming because House wants to be there for Wilson?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yes. You're new.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We got a case. Six-year-old with a nosebleed and breathing problems. She was born with a rare mutation of AT.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: Emily has a unique variant on both of her ATM genes. Her disorder mimics AT, but not all of the symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This is Dr. Elizabeth Lawson. She's a developmental geneticist attached to JHU and an expert on the girl's condition.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Elizabeth Lawson. Emily Lawson.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: I'm here as a doctor, not a mother.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Nosebleeds and breathing problems are common symptoms of ataxia telangiectasia.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: We could just be seeing the natural progression of—

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: It's not. AT patients have a life expectancy of 20 years. Emily is only six. It's something else. I examined her lungs two days ago. They're functioning normally.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: It says she fell off a carousel. Head trauma—

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: If the diagnosis was easy, I wouldn't need you people. I'm here because, according to Eric, you're the best.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: We are. Have you considered Wegener's granulomatosis?

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: It's a good fit. But she can't have X-rays. AT makes her hypersensitive to ionizing radiation. I'll get her prepped for an MRI.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She knows more about her daughter's genetic condition than any of you. She'll be an asset.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Or she won't, Eric.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This isn't a request. Use her.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm more interested in exactly how you plan to do that, Mike.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And, if it hasn't shrunk enough after that, I'm dead.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Catching it in time would have been before it invaded the tissue around my thymus. I want the radiation and the chemo concurrently.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm gonna get a second opinion.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We're done here. I'll look for a doctor with some actual balls.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I agree with Wilson.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I meant about the ball-less part. Explains the office.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: It was a merry-go-round. She's a kid, Liz. We were having fun. You should try it sometime.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: Fun? She's six, not you. You know she has balance issues.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: I know that she's—

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: This is Emily's father, Simon. He was with her when the symptoms occurred.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: I had her all week. She was fine.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We could come back.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: No need. Patient's ready for transport.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: Wake up, sleepy head. I saw it in the gift shop. I know how much you like them.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Thanks.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: They're gonna take you for an MRI now.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: It means "magic really cool images."

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: I thought it stood for "magnetic resonance imaging."

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: We've spent a lot of time in hospitals.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hit. And I hate you. Ugh. I'm done.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I sunk your battleship?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. But I think I'm gonna puke.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good. Now that you're sufficiently buzzed, what was the reason behind you freaking out on Kondo? Are you scared? In denial?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I know you get confused any time someone thinks that you're wrong, but it's not considered freaking out for a patient to ask for a second opinion.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, well, here it is. Kondo is right. You should be in radiology right now.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well done. You've kept your word for almost two hours.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Every day you wait, our pal toomie is growing larger in your chest. If you want to live, stop screwing around and do something about it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Good idea. I think I'll start with spending spring break on my own.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: How you feeling in there, Emily?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Good, I guess.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Is something wrong?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: I was only pretending to be asleep. You think that's dishonest?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Uh, that's—

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: My daughters do that too. But they know that sometimes, when it seems like mommy and daddy are fighting, it's really only because they're worried about you.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: And does your wife ever want a divorce?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No. Everything's fine at home. Hold still now. No more talking.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: What do you think of her mother? She called her daughter "the patient.”

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: If my kids were born with an expiration date, I don't—

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Ow!

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Ow! Ow-ee!

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Where does it hurt?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: I want my daddy. Where's my daddy? Ow! Ow!

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We were able to restore circulation to her hands and feet before any permanent damage set in.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Primary Raynaud's? The cold inside the MRI room could have set it off.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Stress can also precipitate the condition.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: She's shown no evidence of cold sensitivity, and she has no problems with MRI machines.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: There are other kinds of stress. She heard you and your husband

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: Unfortunately, she's heard a lot worse than that before. It's not stress.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Could be secondary Raynaud's. Lupus is consistent with Emily's symptoms

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: Her lymph nodes aren't enlarged, and she has shown no signs of immune activation. It could be heavy metal poisoning.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: From what? The carousel? She was only on it for a minute.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: Simon moved into an old apartment building three weeks ago. I'm sure he has no idea what the insulation's made of, what kind of paint. He's a good father, but when it comes to Emily's health — I'm gonna get his keys and check for environmentals.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Lupus is a better fit.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: I don't mean to pull rank here, but I am her mother.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I thought you said you were here as a doctor.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: And as a doctor, I need parental consent. See above. While I'm gone, please start her on Chelation Therapy.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She's the mother. So let's treat her like any other mother.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I think we just hit the environmental mother lode. Funny she never mentioned an entire basement full of dangerous chemicals and drugs.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You think she'd even let Emily down here?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah. Apparently a lot.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You ever heard of Lex-2?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Read about it. It's an experimental aminoglycoside antibiotic. Supposedly it can override DNA errors in the ATM gene.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Doesn't mean she's giving it to her daughter. Anyone studying A-T would be researching it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: How? You see any lab rats down here? The only cage I see is right there.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Go away. I have a headache.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We don't have to have sex. Sometimes it's nice just to cuddle and talk. Me first. You don't want a second opinion. You're already on your fifth. You got Evans at Mercy, Shaw at County, Foster at Johns Hopkins. And every one of them has given you the same advice. You're nuts. You don't just want chemo. You want a dose so high, there's a one-in-three chance it'll kill you outright. Question is, why didn't you tell me? Because you knew I'd stop you. Which means you've already found someone insane enough or desperate enough to give you what amounts to a death dose of chemicals. But who would be that stupid? I'm thinking that the who, is you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where exactly were you planning on killing yourself? 'Cause I don't think Foreman is gonna let you do it here.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: My place. I've been stockpiling equipment.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. No! Stop. I'm still healthy. Why not go the extreme route now when there's a better chance of surviving it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Statistically, this treatment has about the same chance of killing you as the thymoma does. But a hell of a lot faster.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I am not going to die slowly in a hospital bed under fluorescent lighting with people stopping by to gawk and lie about how I look. Even a small chance of that happening is too big a chance for me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're an idiot. And the odds say you're gonna die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We'll do it at my place.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The only environmental factors we think caused your daughter's illness are the ones you shot her full of.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: I tested the drug. This is what I did for a living for ten years.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: She's your child, not a Guinea pig.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: I tested it first. On myself. And in six months, I didn't document any adverse effects.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A trial of one is basically irrelevant.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: Respiratory infections are common with AT. With Emily's mutation, they are deadly, and they get worse every year. Lex-2 won't be approved for at least the next five years. Emily, on the other hand, wouldn't have survived the winter. What was I supposed to do?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There's a reason for FDA requirements. A study at Jackson Memorial—

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: I know about Gaines' research. He's publishing next month.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Was. I just spoke to him. His team just linked the use of Lex-2 to renal failure in mice and rats.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She needs an ultrasound guided renal biopsy to check the damage. Hopefully it's reversible.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To stupidity.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mm, not quite done. To muscle aches, spasms. To your joints feeling like they're being ripped out and replaced with shards of broken glass.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Should I be writing any of this down?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your stomach fills with bile. When you vomit, it feels like someone's forcing a white-hot hammer down your esophagus, tearing your flesh. Blood's dripping down the back of your throat, choking and gagging you with the slick, coppery taste of burnt pennies.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I am an Oncologist. I know—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you did, we wouldn't be sitting here. Day two: Your white blood cells are gone, opening up your system to attack. Your temperature skyrockets. One second, your skin feels like it's on fire. The next second, it's entombed in ice. Every pain sensor in your body is firing at the same time until agony isn't even a word or a concept — it's your only reality. You hallucinate. You dream of death. And then the race begins. Can your body claw its way back in time before the hostile organisms and parasites claim you permanently? Win, you live. Lose, you die. Now, what are we doing here, Wilson?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Kidney number one looks good. Which means we'll probably take the biopsy from two.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Hey, you're doing great. Brave as always.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Pretty cool, eh? You want to try?

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: What's wrong?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: My chest hurts.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It's definitely not her kidneys.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Promise this'll taste just as good coming up as it did going down.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If things go wrong, I just want you to know—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you're gonna say that you've always been secretly gay for me, everyone always just kind of assumed it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I just want you to know… that I appreciate the risk you're taking… Pumping a human being full of lethal chemicals in your living room. If I die, it probably won't go over well with your probation officer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's not gonna be an issue.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm glad at least one of us is confident.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not me. I've already identified a couple of spots to dump your body if this goes south.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I've always enjoyed Trinity Park.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It does have a nice access to the lake.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Muscle spasms already?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. It's nothing really.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good news. Takes most people two bags to get to that stage. You're way ahead of schedule.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You'll think it's stupid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That hasn't stopped you before.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I just always thought, when I got old or sick, I'd have a wife or kids to look after me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And in this scenario, are your loving wife and kids holding the life support cord, or are they thumbing through your will? I'm in it, right?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Mm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have everything you need right here. We both do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Painkiller. Industrial strength. Level: Awesome.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We're on vacation.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Aahh! That is nice.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Her kidneys are fine. I don't think we're looking at side effects from the Lex-2.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: She's prone to respiratory infection. Pneumonia?

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: No persistent cough, chills, or excess sweating.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What about a pulmonary embolism?

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Fits coughing up blood, but a clot. From what?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Bruising from when she fell off the carousel. Contusion damages a deep vein, causes a clot. A piece breaks off, travels to her lungs.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: We need to get her on heparin now. Another embolism could cause a heart attack or a stroke.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: What's wrong? Is it Emily?

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Sort of.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: You can't do this.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: I'm taking her to Mercy. Everything you people have done has just made her worse.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: You don't have the right. We have joint custody.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Where was my right when you were treating our daughter like a lab rat?

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: She'd be dead if I hadn't.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Stop it. Your daughter deserves better than this.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: It's okay, sweetie.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Mommy and I are just gonna talk. Okay?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You want to get some candy?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We believe Emily has a clot in her lungs. If you leave now, she could die before her new doctors are even up to speed.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: From her AT?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: From the fall off the carousel.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: Now can we just stop blaming each other and do the right thing here?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: You're really gonna equate the two?

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: No, you were giving her two minutes of fun. I was trying to save her life.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: What's her best friend's name? What's the name of her favorite teacher? Why does she hate that stuffed animal you gave her? She's been having nightmares about penguins all month.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: What's her blood type? Rh factor? Her serum immunoglobulin levels?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: I don't care. I don’t care. Those are letters and numbers. That's not her.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: What about the variant in her E-14 ATM intergenic promoter region? Because that's what's killing our daughter. Unless I can find a way to reactivate it.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Just make her better.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: You don't look too good mister.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How did you get in here?

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: The door. Are you, like, sick or something?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Where's House? Where are your parents? Oh, I know you. You live in the building, right? What's your name?

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: You don't remember?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: You promised me I'd go home again, Dr. Wilson.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: You said it wasn't my fault.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It wasn't, John.

utterance.speaker: John
utterance.content: If I didn't do nothing wrong, why did I die?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I don't know. I shouldn't have done this. Am I dead?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not yet. It just feels that way. Are you okay? I mean, apart from the pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and cramps?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I worked six months in a research lab after med school. You get so focused. Once I didn't eat for two days. It's easy to forget what actually matters.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: I didn't. Yeah, it sucks I got her the wrong doll, but…

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Good news. Emily's lungs are clear. No clot.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: And bad news. We still don't know what's happening to her.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Whatever it is, there's liver involvement. Her eyes are jaundiced. Her liver's failing.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We found a blockage in her hepatic vein, which is restricting blood flow to her liver.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Polycythemia vera?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Red blood counts are normal. Could be some sort of connective tissue disorder.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: What if — what if we're just seeing the end result of her condition? She's unique. One screwed-up gene from each of us.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Let's stick with our process.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: I shouldn't be here.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What are we missing?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Advanced Lyme disease.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Would have seen it in the blood.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He said advanced. We wouldn't pick it up in her blood if it's in her organs and nervous system now. It fits everything but the nosebleed.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: But why is it attacking now, all at once? What's changed?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Elizabeth has. She stopped giving Emily the Lex-2. It's an aminoglycoside antibiotic. It's what was keeping the Lyme in check.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We need to start her on amoxicillin.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Mm.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You lied. Doesn't taste better coming back up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Here's another one. You look good.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What's the white blood cell count?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's down to 1,000, still dropping.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I need more morphine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We're out. You've been using my personal supply of painkillers for the last eight hours.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You have — you have enough for both of us?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I've got enough stashed around here for a minyan.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Mm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just remember they're a gift. So it's rude to keep throwing them up. Found that out with those candlesticks you got me.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We think it's Lyme.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: I would have seen signs of that.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Not if the Lex-2 was keeping it in check.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: We live in the city. We don't have pets. She's never even been in the woods.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Yes, I have. With daddy.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: I should have told you, but I know how you feel about it. I grew up hunting with my dad. I wanted to share it with my daughter, at least once.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: We only took pictures. You don't need to be mad.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Maybe we should step outside.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: No. We can't protect her from everything. I assume you'll need a lumbar puncture to confirm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You lost a contact?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Going to the little boy's room.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They're called adult diapers for a reason. Use it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I did, and if you think I'm gonna let you change me—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's okay. I'm a doctor.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hey! Just leave me alone.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's pathetic. I'm pathetic. An oncologist with cancer. Of all the things that could be killing me… It's like the universe is giving me the big middle finger.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The universe doesn't care—

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why me? I'm always telling my patients not to torture themselves, because there's no answer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sound advice.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's cruel advice. They were just trying to make sense of what was happening to them, and I'm there telling them not to bother? I should have spent my life being more like you. Should have been a manipulative, self-centered, narcissistic ass, who brought misery to everything and everyone in his life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You'd still have cancer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah! But at least I'd feel like I deserved it.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Do you think my parents will get back together?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I don't know. I'm sure they love each other, but—

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: They only fight about me.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: That's because they care so much.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: So maybe when I die, they'll get back together.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Emily, what's wrong?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: I can't move my arm.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Just keep your arms up for me.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: What's happening to her?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She's having a stroke.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, your heart rate's up, BP's tanking. White blood count's

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't have the equipment or the meds to handle this.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. Win or lose. Win or lose. That was the deal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That was the deal when there was an "or". You can't win this.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. No. I'd rather die here. Not in an ambulance. Not in a hospital. Please, you can't do that to me. I can't — House… Please. Promise me that you won't do that to me. Promise me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, I promise.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Stroke. Blockage in her hepatic vein, coughing blood, trouble breathing, and Raynaud's.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: If we hadn't already ruled it out, it sounds like textbook pulmonary embolism.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What mimics a clot but isn't a clot?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Fungal infection.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Her CSF was clean. No bacterial or fungal markers. Anyone tried calling House?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Not picking up.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Or returning messages or texts.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We're on our own here, so just give me some theories we can use.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Hematologic malignancies. AT patients are more prone to that form of cancer.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You think cancer would present and kill her in three days

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not cancer. But a tumor could act like a clot. An atrial myxoma.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A primary heart tumor. The swinging motion of the myxoma intermittently blocked the flow of blood through the right atrium. Inflow blockage stagnated the hepatic vein, which clotted and caused liver failure. Outflow blockage caused the Raynaud's phenomenon and stroke. Pieces of the tumor broke off and lodged in the lungs, causing Emily’s breathing problems and the coughing blood. We'll remove the tumor surgically, and hopefully the biopsy reveals it's benign.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Wow. You — you really look like crap.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Been fighting a cold lately. Seven to ten days for the swelling to go down. Then we rescan and schedule the surgery.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I seem to recall, I said some things to you—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You talked a lot. I stopped listening after you confessed your fear of dolphins. Can we just tone down the bromance a few notches? My leg is killing me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: One last favor. I'd like to actually make it to the bathroom this time.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I thought you said you had plenty of Vicodin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Everybody lies.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So the way I felt, you feel that, what, most of the time? It really does suck being you, doesn't it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: At least I don't have cancer.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The tumor was benign.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: And we were able to remove all of it.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Does this mean I'm not sick anymore?

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: No, honey. The tumor didn't cause your genetic condition. You're still sick.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: But we never let that stop us before, right? So what do you want to do when we get out of here?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Have you been to the aquarium? It's pretty cool.

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Can we go, daddy?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: You bet.

utterance.speaker: Elizabeth
utterance.content: Me too?

utterance.speaker: Emily
utterance.content: Can she come with us?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: You know mommy never has to ask.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'll see you at lunch.
